#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Register an Animal
#Text=If you have some sort of disability , you may want or need a support animal to help you in your day-to-day life .
#Text=The 2 main types of support animals are service animals and emotional support animals .
#Text=These different types of support animal are subject to different laws and certification requirements .
#Text=However , once you know what this necessary certification is , getting the right paperwork for your animal is a breeze .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Qualifying for a Support Animal
#Text=Determine what type of support animal you need .
#Text=Service dogs are individually trained to perform critical daily functions for people with physical or psychiatric disabilities .
#Text=Emotional support animals ( ESA ) , on the other hand , are not trained , but instead offer support for individuals suffering from psychiatric or emotional disabilities .
#Text=Most individuals with service dogs suffer from a severe disability , such as blindness or asthma , that makes it very difficult to perform major life tasks .
#Text=These dogs are then trained to help the individual perform that major life task ( e. g. , helping a person with limited sight get around in public ) .
#Text=The Americans with Disabilities Act ( ADA ) defines “ disability ” very broadly , so do n't feel like yours is n't a “ real ” disability just because it 's not as bad as someone else 's .
#Text=Anything that makes a normal function of life difficult qualifies as a disability .
#Text=Have a doctor formally diagnose your disability .
#Text=Although this is n't required by law , a doctor will be able to tell you whether obtaining or training a service dog is the best thing for you .
#Text=If you do n't already have a dog , the doctor may also be able to refer you to a reputable provider of properly trained service animals .
#Text=Note that you 're not required to obtain a service dog from a professional training program .
#Text=You can also train your own service dog yourself , if you feel up to the task .
#Text=Be prescribed an emotional support animal for any mental health issues .
#Text=ESAs are not covered by the ADA , but they are still protected by other laws that prevent discrimination against disabled individuals .
#Text=In order for your animal to be covered , though , it needs to have been formally prescribed to you by a mental health professional .
#Text=This prescription can be in the form of a formally written letter from your therapist or counselor , stating that the presence of your ESA is necessary for your mental or emotional health .

#Text=The Fair Housing Act ( FHA ) says that landlords cannot bar your ESA from living with you , while the Department of Transportation also requires airlines to allow passengers with mental and emotional disabilities to fly with their ESAs .
#Text=Make sure your animal is well-behaved enough to be a support animal .
#Text=Apart from the particular training that service dogs are required to have , the only other behavioral requirement for support animals is that they not behave inappropriately in public .
#Text=This can include behaving aggressively , biting or scratching other dogs or people , toileting inappropriately , or otherwise disrupting business .

#Text=If your support animal is not well behaved , businesses can then legally bar you and your animal from entering the premises , since the animal constitutes a “ direct threat ” or “ fundamental alteration ” to their business .
#Text=Train your dog to do a vital function , if you want it to be a service dog .
#Text=Remember , service dogs must be able to do a specific task , not just provide emotional support .
#Text=If you already own a dog , teach it to help you perform a major life task in order to have it qualify as a service dog .
#Text=This task can be something as simple as helping you cross the street if you have limited vision or barking for assistance when you have trouble breathing .
#Text=Note that this type of training can be very time-consuming , sometimes taking several years .
#Text=If your disability is particularly urgent , you may be better off just buying a dog that has already been trained .
#Text=Getting the Right Paperwork
#Text=Get certification for your ESA from a mental health professional .
#Text=Have your therapist , counselor , or psychiatrist write you a formal letter stating that you have a mental or emotional disability and that having your ESA is necessary for your mental health .
#Text=If possible , have your doctor write this letter on a professional letterhead to give it an added layer of legitimacy .
#Text=If you do n't have a formal therapist , or your therapist is unwilling to write you a letter , you may be able to use an online mental health service to acquire this type of letter .
#Text=However , be very careful when using this type of service , since many of these types of websites may be scams .
#Text=Carry this letter with you so you can use it as documentation for an ESA .
#Text=You 'll need to provide this letter to a landlord or airline employee who asks to see your ESA 's certification .
#Text=Just to be safe , keep a scanned copy of this letter in your home while carrying the other copy with you at all times .
#Text=Note that this is the only documentation the law requires ESAs to have .
#Text=Avoid paying a website to “ register ” your support animal .
#Text=Apart from having a formal letter from a mental health professional , support animals are not required by law to be certified or registered to any database .
#Text=Websites that try to sell this type of certification are usually trying to sell to people who do n't actually know the law , so just steer clear of them .
#Text=Oftentimes , people will pay to “ register ” their pets as support animals because they think it 's required or they think it makes their support animal look more official .
#Text=In reality , anyone who understands the law will probably think the person using this type of certification does n't actually qualify for a support animal .
#Text=Be aware that you do n't need to show documentation for a service dog .
#Text=According to the ADA , business owners and employees are not allowed to demand documentation for your service dog .
#Text=Instead , they 're only allowed to ask if the animal is required because of a disability and what task the animal has been trained to do .
#Text=Owners and employees are also not allowed to demand that the dog demonstrate its task or ask about the nature of your disability .
